abstract: An indication of a scene’s operational state.
overview:
## Overview

The system moves your app’s [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Scene] instances through phases that reflect a scene’s operational state. You can trigger actions when the phase changes. Read the current phase by observing the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/EnvironmentValues/scenePhase] value in the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/Environment]:

How you interpret the value depends on where it’s read from. If you read the phase from inside a [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View] instance, you obtain a value that reflects the phase of the scene that contains the view. The following example uses the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/View/onChange(of:initial:_:)-8wgw9] method to enable a timer whenever the enclosing scene enters the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/ScenePhase/active] phase and disable the timer when entering any other phase:

If you read the phase from within an [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/App] instance, you obtain an aggregate value that reflects the phases of all the scenes in your app. The app reports a value of [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/ScenePhase/active] if any scene is active, or a value of [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/ScenePhase/inactive] when no scenes are active. This includes multiple scene instances created from a single scene declaration; for example, from a [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/WindowGroup]. When an app enters the [doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/SwiftUI/ScenePhase/background] phase, expect the app to terminate soon after. You can use that opportunity to free any resources:
